bibl.title: Letter from Carlos E. Finlay to George A. Kellogg, August 6, 1941

div1.p: Carlos E. Finlay expresses his dissatisfaction with Cornwell's painting, "Conquerors of Yellow Fever."

div1.head: Letter from Carlos E. Finlay to George A. Kellogg, August 6, 1941
div1.opener:
Dr. C.E.Finlay
Linea Numero 710
Telefono F-4730
C O P Y
Vedado, Habana
Cuba
August 6, 1941
My dear Mr. Kellogg:
div1.p:
I beg to acknowledge receipt of your
letter of July 28 with the enclosed clippings
for which accept my thanks.

I am sorry to belong to the people who
do not like the painting.

The likeness of my father I do not con-
sider good and the cut of his clothes not like
what he used to wear.

The painting moreover lacks in historical
accuracy, of the people appearing in it only Lazear
and possibly Agramonte, besides Carroll himself
were present, General Wood was not present, Reed
was absent in the States, my father was not cog-
nizant of the inoculation till much later. This
inoculation like all the others by the Commission
and my father were not conducted in the spectacular
form here depicted but in the privacy of the inocu-
lator's office. Dr. Carroll gave so little import
to his inoculation, which was preceded by 7 failures
that when he fell sick he thought he had malaria
forgetting all about his mosquito inoculation (see
Dr. Agramonte's letter to my father on page 222 of
my book)

In my opinion it would have been much more
appropriate and historically correct to have taken
as subject matter of the painting the handing of the
mosquito eggs to the Commission by my father. In
view of this idea not having been utilized, we will
probably have it carried out by a local painter.

I will be glad to accept the reproduction you
refer to.

Hoping you will excuse my frak criticism, I
am,
